Management of the Information Economy

Information logistics, eliciting information demand, stakeholders, personas, and the Balanced Scorecard

Information Logistics (Augustin, 1990)

The Information Economy is the demand-side layer of the Krcmar model. Its core problem: organizations have data, but decision-makers need information — relevant, timely, and contextualized.

Definition: The logistical principle (Augustin, 1990) states that we must supply the right information, at the right time, in the right amount, at the right place, in the required quality.

The Information Logistics Cycle

1. Information Demand
↓
Requirements
2. Information Sources
↓
Enable processing
3. Information Resources
↓
Customize
4. Information Supply
↻
Back to Demand
StageQuestion
Information DemandWhat do stakeholders require?
Information SourcesWhich internal/external sources are available?
Information ResourcesHow do we transform raw sources into usable form?
Information SupplyHow do we deliver it at the right time?

Eliciting Information Demand

Three sub-steps: identify stakeholders and personas, elicit people’s needs (subjective), and understand company needs (objective).

Picot’s Three Dimensions (Picot, 1988)

Information Demand = the intersection of three dimensions: Objective Need (what’s necessary for the task), Subjective Need (what’s perceived necessary), and Available Information (what exists).

Objective Need
Task-necessary
Subjective Need
Perceived necessary
Available Info
What exists
↘ ↓ ↙
Information Demand
= where all three overlap

The gaps between dimensions have specific meanings:

GapMeaningImplication
Objective but not SubjectivePerson doesn’t realize they need itTraining gap
Subjective but not ObjectivePerson thinks they need it, but it’s not task-relevantNoise / information overload
Needed but not AvailableInformation doesn’t exist or isn’t accessibleInformation gap — needs new sources
Available but not NeededExists but no one requires itOverload risk
ApproachMethodExamples
SubjectiveDerive from personal interpretationInterviews, wishlists
ObjectiveDerive from inter-subjectively validated interpretationStrategic analysis, process analysis
MixedObjective first, then subjectiveProcess analysis → interviews

Stakeholders and Personas

Definition: A stakeholder is a person or organization who influences a system’s requirements or who is impacted by that system. Influence can also be indirect (Glinz, 2020).

LevelStakeholder TypesInformation Focus
StrategicSenior managementStrategic direction, high-level KPIs
TacticalMiddle management, knowledge workersDepartmental performance, resource allocation
OperationalOperational managers, data workersDay-to-day operations, task instructions

Important: Different stakeholders view the same system from entirely different perspectives. Accounting for all views is essential for complete requirements.

Personas are fictional individuals representing a user group, built from empirical data (interviews, analytics). Each captures demographics, goals, frustrations, and motivations — providing concrete guidance instead of designing for a vague user.

The Balanced Scorecard (Kaplan & Norton, 1992)

The Balanced Scorecard (BSC) links firm strategy and objectives to measurable indicators across four perspectives. The arrows are bidirectional: strategy defines what to measure, and measurements feed back to adjust strategy.

Financial
Cash flow · ROI · Return on capital · Return on equity
↕
Customers
Satisfaction · Loyalty · Retention · Quality
↔
Firm Strategy
and Objectives
↔
Business Processes
Execution time · Resource efficiency · Downtime
↕
Learning and Growth
Investment rate · Employee turnover · Internal promotions
PerspectiveGuiding QuestionComponents
FinancialHow should we appear to our shareholders?Objectives, Measures, Targets, Initiatives
CustomerHow should we appear to our customers?Objectives, Measures, Targets, Initiatives
Internal Business ProcessWhat processes must we excel at?Objectives, Measures, Targets, Initiatives
Learning and GrowthHow will we sustain our ability to change and improve?Objectives, Measures, Targets, Initiatives

Important: The BSC is not just a set of KPIs — it explicitly links Vision and Strategy to measurable outcomes across all four perspectives, ensuring information demand is derived from strategic objectives rather than ad-hoc requests. The BSC provides the objective side of Picot’s framework.

Information Sources & Resources

Source/Demand Matrix

Internal Source
External Source
Internal Demand
Enterprise Systems
Specialized information
External Demand
Publications, P.R., Investor relations

The primary IM focus is fulfilling internal demand via enterprise systems (top-left cell).

Information Quality

ContextualPresentationalIntrinsicAccess
CurrentnessUnderstandabilityReliabilityAccessibility
CompletenessClarityCorrectnessMaintainability
Appropriate ScopeUniformityObjectivity
RelevanceUnambiguityCredibility

Important: Even correct information can fail if it is not current, accessible, or understandable. All four quality dimensions must be considered.

Sources vs. Resources

An information source is any origin of data (database, report, person). When a source is used recurrently and managed for reuse, it becomes an information resource. Sources are discovered; resources are engineered — organized, indexed, and maintained for efficient reuse.

Organizing Resources

ApproachStructureExamples
HierarchiesTree-structured classificationTaxonomy
KeywordsFlat or semi-structured labelsThesaurus, Tags
GraphsNetwork of linked conceptsSemantic Web

Taxonomies

A taxonomy is a hierarchical classification: a set of labels L and relationships R where r = ⟨l₁, l₂⟩. Labels are either instances (specific individuals) or classes (categories), with relationships being is-a or member-of accordingly.

Important: Taxonomy relationships can form directed acyclic graphs (not just strict trees) — a label can appear under multiple parents.

The Semantic Web (Tim Berners-Lee)

The Semantic Web is the graph-based approach: machines understand meaning, not just syntax. Architecture layers: URI/Unicode (identifiers) → XML (syntax) → RDF triples (subject–predicate–object data model) → Ontologies (shared vocabularies). For IM, it enables cross-system linking through shared ontologies, reducing data silos.

Information Supply: Data Warehouse & ETL

Definition: A Data Warehouse consolidates data from multiple operational systems into a single, query-optimized repository for analysis and reporting.

Operational System
ERP
CRM
Flat Files
→
ETL
Extraction
Transformation
Loading
→
Data Warehouse
Metadata
Summary Data
Raw Data
→
OLAP Analysis
Reporting
Data Mining
StageProcessPurpose
ExtractionPull data from multiple heterogeneous source systemsGather raw operational data
TransformationClean, standardize, and restructure the dataEnsure consistency and quality
LoadingStore the processed data in the warehouseMake it available for analysis

Transformation is the most complex ETL step: data cleaning (fixing errors, missing values), deduplication, format standardization (dates, units, encodings), business rule application (derived fields), and schema mapping (aligning source schemas to target). Without proper transformation, the warehouse inherits source system inconsistencies.
